revised_title: Reflex Inhibition of the Knee Flexor: Influence of Afferent Nerves and Background Contractions
tldr: This study investigates the reflex inhibition of the knee flexor muscle using a decerebrate preparation and examines the influence of afferent nerves from the contralateral hind-limb. The results show that the contralateral afferent nerves predominantly cause inhibition, which is stronger with stronger intercurrent stimuli. The study also demonstrates that the effect of the intercurrent stimulation can change from inhibition to excitation depending on the intensity of the background contraction.
